You could read the entire wiki behind this game and its predecessor, Elona, and still not have a clear idea of what it‚Äôs actually about. You could watch reviews from people like SsethTzeentach and be completely befuddled by the sheer absurdity of the variety of content available to you as a player. You could even read every Steam review for this game, and you'd probably draw the same conclusion as I did before actually giving it a try: [b]Elin is a game that no amount of explanation can do justice - you just have to play it.[/b] That being said, [strike]I'm built different, so my review will definitely be the reason you choose to buy Elin![/strike] here's my best attempt at describing this gem...

[h1]Elin is not [i]just[/i] a Sandbox, Roguelite JRPG:
[u]it‚Äôs a mirror to your soul[/u].[/h1]

If you‚Äôve seen other reviews and become discouraged by the levels of depravity you can engage in, know that the game is [i]only as weird as you are.[/i] You don‚Äôt HAVE to engage in slavery, prostitution, drug trade, cannibalism, etc. If you just want to be a wholesome turnip farmer with a cozy ranch full of chickens, ducks, cows, sheep, and goats, go for it. Alternatively, you could grow crops to turn into drugs and alcohol, and have monstergirls and humans as livestock [spoiler](slaves)[/spoiler], instead. If you want to be an alcoholic dwarf that beats the crap out of people with hammers, worship the god of weightlifting and mining, and carry around an entire piano for both entertaining and killing people, GO FOR IT! Want to be a wizard that pulls out a shotgun when you run out of mana? You get the picture - go for it - you can do whatever the heck you want.

[h2]Elin is special because it commits itself to prioritizing player fun and freedom. Your playthrough will never be exactly like any other, and that‚Äôs what‚Äôs so beautiful about it.[/h2]

[b]Closing thoughts:[/b] the game is constantly being updated by a developer who candidly loves what he does. There's passion oozing out of every aspect of this game, and you‚Äôd be doing yourself a disservice if you didn't at least give the free demo a shot. The only drawback of the demo is that your character has a level cap of 10 or so. Besides that, you virtually have access to the entirety of the game.

Thank you, Shuridood, for gifting me this amazing masterpiece of a game. If this is how addicting it is in early access, I can‚Äôt wait to see how amazing the finished product will be! Countless combinations of races, classes, builds, etc. and a fun story and lore-rich world to enjoy! This game truly is a gift that keeps on giving.

[h3]BONUS TIPS[/h3]
[spoiler]If you do decide to try/buy Elin, experiment! Your first hour should be spent goofing around with 2 or 3 characters with different builds so you can get a feel for the game. I started out as several kinds of humans: Juere, Yerles, etc. and tried being a thief, gunner, and farmer. I quickly learned that race and class are mostly for roleplay flavor and early game bonuses. There are things that make races and classes unique, yes, but you're never locked out of achieving what most of them can by middle-to-late game.

So, if you're looking at all the possibilities and suffering from anxiety or indecision, JUST PICK SOMETHING. Pick what sounds cool to you and you will have fun and figure it out as you go. You've also got a 90-day buffer of no penalties from dying, so use and abuse that to fuck around and see just how much trouble you can get into.

What race and class did I ultimately pick? Elean Priest. Why? Because elves are cool and holy magic is cool. No regrets and I've enjoyed over 100 hours with that character. 

TL:DR
ALL BUILDS ARE VIABLE, SO PLAY AS WHATEVER YOU WANT.[/spoiler]

Verdict: 
   This game while not yet finished is already in a more complete state than many final products. It is playable but a bit empty outside of the core gameplay loop at this time. Probably worth somewhere between 10 and 18 Euros (or up to $20 Dollars US) now or so.

Summary:
    In this game you play a customized character with a class, race, and starting age grouping. What this means is what starting skills you have and how quickly they grow. Nothing is locked away except very specific race and class feats. You mostly level stats and skills by using them and eating foods that boost their growth. Training is required to start learning many of them and afterward can boost the speed of growth but that does get used as a resource.
     The plot is still in process and the final point is unclear but so far has a little bit of ancient mystery and political machinations.

Pros:
 + Most features work and there are few bugs. Also has regular updates
 + Good mix of farming, combat, and exploration that don't punish you for neglecting the one you hate
 + A large cast of recruitable characters, both unique and randomly generated
 + Diverse skill sets and equipment to let you make your characters your way
 + Seems very mod community friendly
 + Turn-based but in a slightly different way than most so it almost feels like it isn't

Neutral:
 * Customizable rules so you can go for perma-death, punishing, or easy but somewhat limited options
 * You cannot skip over the early content and associated grind on later characters
 * Can visit other players locations via the "moon gates"

Cons:
 - Very time consuming due to grind if you aren't using the console commands
 - Several skills are very obscure as to how they function with hidden mechanics
 - A LOT of things are RNG reliant on finding, especially recipes for item construction
 - At this time, the only weapon or armor crafting is for wood and stone, also it is random in output
 - Many materials are too difficult to reliably obtain and severely limit crafting due to this

Conclusion:
   This game is actually a lot of fun and sometimes addicting if you are into this style of play and combat but doesn't respect the players real world time very well. It can become a grind fest and many of the skills and recipes are VERY tedious to actually level past the initial 10-25 levels. An issue given some recipes require levels around 50-60 to fully unlock.
    It looks like it will be a great game once they get the actual quests working and not just the main quest (which is not yet complete). They also need to speed up leveling and crafting times but it could be an amazing finished product if they do so.

TLDR: Great potential, works acceptably, has a bit of a grind issue and RNG resource issue.

Elin is a weird game. There is nothing like it, I can guarantee at least that much. Elin is essentially an open-world traditional roguelike / mystery dungeon game (not to be confused with modern roguelike/roguelite, permadeath is optional). The closest games mechanic-wise are Doors of Trithius, Pokemon Mystery Dungeon, Stoneshard, Shiren, Caves of Qud, or if you are old enough, UnReal World. If you are a long time traditional roguelike player, you'll understand what you're getting into: grid-bound turn-based tactical combat, all objects within the grid are interactable to some degree, classic floor-based levels for dungeon, procedurally generated dungeon, hunger system, etc. Default difficulty does NOT have permadeath, and I suggest to keep it disabled on your first playthrough.

Beyond the surface however, Elin's roguelite-esque progression only applies to the dungeon crawling part of the game. For the rest of the game, Elin borrows a lot of progression system from survival-craft games instead. Gathering, building, crafting, and unlocking recipe will quickly become an integral part of your gameplay loop. For some combat builds, crafting is a necessity even (i.e: gunner's bullet is far cheaper to craft than buying, brewing is also by far the best way to make money). 

At some point, the survival-craft progression will develop into basic colony simulation. You can recruit new party members, workers, and traders to your land. You can gain revenue from tourists by building an inn, or a restaurant, all comes with land value system that determines tourism attraction. The amount of gameplay mechanics in this game will always surprise you no matter your expectation. Just when you thought you've seen it all, more is coming. These mechanics are not completely superfluous either, as they complement the dungeon-crawling part of the game quite well.. for the most part.

This game might give you kenshi-like feeling, especially in the beginning. There is no handholding. The only guiding hand is the main story, but its implementation is extremely subtle. You'll get lost and overwhelmed by the sheer amount of poorly explained mechanics. If experimenting is the beauty of kenshi, you'll love Elin for that. My two-cents is don't be like me; trying to min-max my first run. This game is fun to min-max AFTER you learn enough, so save yourself a headache.

In summary, Elin is a complex yet wacky combination of traditional roguelike, survival-craft, and colony sim that will keep you coming back.

This game at its core is a turn-based roguelike dungeon crawler with a deep combat system with numerous stats, spells, and loot that allow you to define a character build just for you. There is a high degree of freedom in creating your own class & character and picking your own playstyle, You can be a frontline tank with a sword&shield, or you can hang back and sling spells & projectiles while your companions take the heat. You can even completely ignore the combat aspect of the game and play it like Stardew Valley/Minecraft by building up your own settlement and recruiting various NPC's to make your own more prosperous and generate revenue through their services. You can practically recruit any NPC to your party in the game, including even some enemy creatures, as long as you build up high enough affinity with them, and this in turn allows them to be useful either in your town, or in your combat party. The freedom of choice in this sandbox is, in my view, unparalleled and every action, every decision holds a tangible reward regardless if you are a pure combat enthusiast or a settlement-builder. With the creator providing regular updates with new content for the Stable version (near-constant if you decide to play the Nightly version, but potentially more buggy), there are potentially hundreds of hours of gameplay waiting for you here.

Might be a bit overwhelming at first when you don't understand how many underlying systems there are and how they interact, especially if you're new to roguelikes, but I suggest taking it slow at the beginning and just explore the world at your leisure. The game's not a linear RPG and there is no in-game time limit. The tutorials and documentation in this game, while they exist, do not capture and explain the full scope of the systems of the game; I recommend checking out Ylvapedia for a more in-depth, community driven compendium for the game's systems.

[h1]Warning: Utter Insanity[/h1]
I have no idea wtf is going on in Elin. Heck, I played Elona for many, many, MANY hours and I have no bloody clue what is going on in Elin or Elona. Now, if you read the wiki, skim the subreddit and then the Steam forums, guess what?

Nobody else really knows what the hell is happening either. We're busy making pizza for the king of the realm just to mix insects into the dough. Why? To get fertilized human eggs, of course!

[h1]Survival Sandbox Thingy[/h1]
So, what is Elin? Elin is a survival sandbox that allows you to create a character with many unique options to choose from and then go on your merry way. Will you be an enthusiastic farmer who seeks out the perfect tomato by carefully selecting which seed to cultivate, gaining power in the process? Run a tourist trap? Dive deep into dangerous dungeons seeking untold riches and legendary weapons?

All of the above? It's possible. Oh, Elin also has a storyline that you should follow for extra goodies I guess. But take your time. In fact, take a lot of time.

[h1]The Long Grind[/h1]
Elin has a ton of skills and you don't start with most of them. The ones you don't have need to be bought with platinum coins, which you will also need to increase your potential with known skills. Potential is a multiplier to XP that will decay as you get more proficient. As you level up skills, the related attribute will increase, which also has potential.

Overall, Elin has a lot of skills, a lot of grinding and what some might consider slow progression. I don't mind it, but one should be aware of it.

On the plus side, if you feel like you messed up and cannot keep up with the increasing difficulty of the encounters, you can always get rid of some fame (the metric that dictates it) and even get some spare change out of it. And no build is invalid either, experimentation and resource management is the key.

[h1]Exploits[/h1]
The wiki will tell you a lot about the general game mechanics and has a few guides. Then there's the subreddit and the community right here on Steam. And no, we most likely haven't remotely figured out what can be done. Elin is an incredibly complex game, with every item and NPC interacting with the world and the player. Killing friendly NPCs for early artifacts, yoinking the tax chest (which is basically the standard these days) and other furniture, finding ways to powergrind certain skills, completely obscure material production chains... it's all out there.

And there's most likely new and exciting ways for us to break it all into bits. If you end up buying this game and find something busted, use it.

That's it. My insane ramblings about a completely unhinged RPG. It's great, period, end of story.

I like how this game looks, and after doing a couple hours on the demo and getting used to all of its systems, I was fairly sure I was going to like it. The presentation is very nice, the tutorial is very comprehensive, and overall it has the delightfully unhinged, procgen energy you'd see in roguelikes like dwarf fortress or caves of Qud, where the chaotic rules of the universe add both comedy and unpredictability to the mix, so, after just a couple of hours mucking around the demo, I decided that I was probably going to enjoy so I bought it.

And then I tried to actually play the game.

I'm not sure if I can properly convey how hard Elin spins its wheels in trying to provide the experience you think it's preparing you for. The first missions will cover basic crafting and survival, however before long, your character will go from expending all their energy twice a day while trying to make a hut, to crossing entire countries without breaking a sweat, as the game will quickly pivot  its focus into finding resources and dungeon delving instead. Even before they have access to decent weapons, your character will be forced to confront caves full of enemies that more often than not you can only hope your pet will take care for you, and I say "hope" because you have no control over your followers: you can't tell them to stop fighting something, and so at points it felt more like my cat was the one playing and I was just there to micromanage their inventory by constantly giving them food and healing items. Mechanics being presented and immediately being pushed into the background, becoming mostly irrelevant but just relevant enough to feel like an annoying chore is a constant with elin as it quickly darts its focus around in one of the most egregious cases of design ADHD I've ever seen.

But that's not even the worst of it, because even if you are underequipped and ill suited at the beginning, you can just grind away until you're able to make it through those missions and progress, right? Wrong. After about 2 ingame weeks, you will be forced to tangle with the horrifying sub boss we will all have to deal with sooner or later [thundercrack]: TAXES. Indeed, you will be forced to drop your probably half finished training missions and travel half the map to the capital to pay your due to fantasy IRS. What's that? Why yes,  you should have started making money oh, about a week ago. Shame you still haven't even finished the introductory missions because you were too busy trying to find vines around your base to make a new bow. To round up the frustrating confusion, the game will withhold several vital items and recipes as rewards for training quests dealing with entirely different systems, so you will always feel like you're missing something while the game crams 3 completely different systems down your throat.

And that's where you ask yourself: [b]what the fuck is this game's point?[/b] It's not a survival crafter since the focus on surviving basically disappears after a couple hours, it's not a dungeon crawler since it keeps pulling you out of it to deal with is economic management systems, but if that's the case why is the economic management aspect of it so poorly set up and uninvolved?! Is it like a sims game where the point is to make pretty houses? Then why try with all these other mechanics when you obviously gave up on them halfway through? Why all this constant flip flopping between undercooked systems? Why are you sending me into a dungeon before giving me the ability to make weapons? Why is my cat capable of aggroing into everything and yet I'm forced to constantly hand-feed it? [b]Why?![/b]

Elin is kinda the yang to Unreal World's ying. While UW is a very rudimentary looking game, with a limited amount of systems that will nonetheless unfold in a comprehensive manner, Elin frontloads its presentation but will lose itself somewhere between wasting your time, withholding information and systems from you, constantly swinging focus, and adding a nice helping of "oh by the way you should have done this differently, you're fucked now. Bye!" on top. The best way I can put it is that the game feels... loose. Like, fundamentally so. i really wanted to like this game. for the first 20 hours or so, it actually was pretty satisfying. (excuse my hour count, i played quite a bit of it while offline.) a friend recommended this one saying that it was as complex and insane as dwarf fortress. at the time, that sounded so awesome that i simply had to take him up on it.

when my review was positive, it talked about all the crazy things that had happened as i was starting out. the pet cat being an alcoholic, receiving a quest to deliver a rather valuable but extremely heavy game table which basically *forces* you to commit mail fraud, etc etc. many people have already talked about such stories. and don't get me wrong, it genuinely was funny for a while!

the problem is that dwarf fortress's insanity is baked into the game itself, whereas elin's insanity is a collection of one-off gags that eventually grow stale. "the quest asked me to deliver what?!?!" "i can, ahem, 'watch birds' with a drunken noblewoman on a street, and that's 20% as bad as just eating cat meat?" "lmao, what did you say this person's age and gender were?" but eventually you stop paying attention to the 20-ish lines of dialog or whatnot from the random civilians, and the quests become the same old thing repeatedly. and all that's left is the gameplay.

it's a total grindfest, basically. i once said that "it's OSRS if it was honest about being a nightmarish capitalist hellscape," which is unfortunately more true of the core mechanics than of the game's setting. some people vibe with that, but there are better uses of my time... after the honeymoon period of setting everything up and growing out of weakling status, it devolves into visiting the same presets of dungeons over and over, travelling between a few towns and handling their quests over and over, praying that you can find something to make your plots of land ever slightly more useful. base building in particular takes a LOT of time, with a number of essential recipes locked behind randomization. beyond a certain point, your rate of income becomes basically linear (or at least, pretty hard to expand into a respectable amount). this becomes a problem when important items are worth hundreds of thousands, while you are making just thousands at a time and it is competing with the steadily-growing taxes.

the aforementioned "dwarf fortress levels of insanity" are really just the limited number of tricks you can use to counteract this tedium, taking advantage of completely randomized object composition (beach ball made of dark matter as a quest reward...) and the fact that almost all creatures in the game behave similarly. humans can have eggs, and you can have conversations with livestock. 

but, again, there's only so much you can do. the combat system is click, click, take advantage of ranged weaponry, pray you don't die. the enemies become beefier but your strategic options don't expand much to counteract that. in particular, the magic system was really cool with how you can collect different spells to defend yourself or teleport out of harm's way. until 30 or so hours in, when you've collected nearly all of the spells and realized they *don't* gradually become more complex to help deal with advanced threats. also, some combat mechanics are quite annoying with few ways to defend against. you can pour water on yourself to protect against fire, or focus on finding acidproof equipment. but there is NOTHING you can do to prevent essential equipment from being shattered by frost, other than buying coldproof blankets, which aren't cheap.

one more minor thing, there's a pretty significant tonal dissonance in this game. i mean that there's a pretty jarring contrast between the supposedly serious story and the often ridiculous, sometimes questionable, backer-suggested content. i guess some people weren't content to make a mod, lol. but this isn't a huge issue. in fact, the insanity would be welcome if that was properly, continuously reflected in the game itself.

overall, it's decent but not mindblowing. i wouldn't bother if it's not on sale. fun for a while, but you might be making a heck of an effort to see the late-game content.

I like how this game looks, and after doing a couple hours on the demo and getting used to all of its systems, I was fairly sure I was going to like it. The presentation is very nice, the tutorial is very comprehensive, and overall it has the delightfully unhinged, procgen energy you'd see in roguelikes like dwarf fortress or caves of Qud, where the chaotic rules of the universe add both comedy and unpredictability to the mix, so, after just a couple of hours mucking around the demo, I decided that I was probably going to enjoy so I bought it.

And then I tried to actually play the game.

I'm not sure if I can properly convey how hard Elin spins its wheels in trying to provide the experience you think it's preparing you for. The first missions will cover basic crafting and survival, however before long, your character will go from expending all their energy twice a day while trying to make a hut, to crossing entire countries without breaking a sweat, as the game will quickly pivot  its focus into finding resources and dungeon delving instead. Even before they have access to decent weapons, your character will be forced to confront caves full of enemies that more often than not you can only hope your pet will take care for you, and I say "hope" because you have no control over your followers: you can't tell them to stop fighting something, and so at points it felt more like my cat was the one playing and I was just there to micromanage their inventory by constantly giving them food and healing items. Mechanics being presented and immediately being pushed into the background, becoming mostly irrelevant but just relevant enough to feel like an annoying chore is a constant with elin as it quickly darts its focus around in one of the most egregious cases of design ADHD I've ever seen.

But that's not even the worst of it, because even if you are underequipped and ill suited at the beginning, you can just grind away until you're able to make it through those missions and progress, right? Wrong. After about 2 ingame weeks, you will be forced to tangle with the horrifying sub boss we will all have to deal with sooner or later [thundercrack]: TAXES. Indeed, you will be forced to drop your probably half finished training missions and travel half the map to the capital to pay your due to fantasy IRS. What's that? Why yes,  you should have started making money oh, about a week ago. Shame you still haven't even finished the introductory missions because you were too busy trying to find vines around your base to make a new bow. To round up the frustrating confusion, the game will withhold several vital items and recipes as rewards for training quests dealing with entirely different systems, so you will always feel like you're missing something while the game crams 3 completely different systems down your throat.

And that's where you ask yourself: [b]what the fuck is this game's point?[/b] It's not a survival crafter since the focus on surviving basically disappears after a couple hours, it's not a dungeon crawler since it keeps pulling you out of it to deal with is economic management systems, but if that's the case why is the economic management aspect of it so poorly set up and uninvolved?! Is it like a sims game where the point is to make pretty houses? Then why try with all these other mechanics when you obviously gave up on them halfway through? Why all this constant flip flopping between undercooked systems? Why are you sending me into a dungeon before giving me the ability to make weapons? Why is my cat capable of aggroing into everything and yet I'm forced to constantly hand-feed it? [b]Why?![/b]

Elin is kinda the yang to Unreal World's ying. While UW is a very rudimentary looking game, with a limited amount of systems that will nonetheless unfold in a comprehensive manner, Elin frontloads its presentation but will lose itself somewhere between wasting your time, withholding information and systems from you, constantly swinging focus, and adding a nice helping of "oh by the way you should have done this differently, you're fucked now. Bye!" on top. The best way I can put it is that the game feels... loose. Like, fundamentally so. Superficially looking like a deep and layered mix of survival crafter and dungeon crawler with a nice sprinkling of economic simulator, but instead being full of mechanical dead ends and nonsensical fluff while constantly changing directions on what it seems to expect from you and deliberately making it confusing and obscure because, on the game's own admission, "well this is a roguelike, so some things will be hard to learn". I've been able to enjoy other roguelikes without ever having too look up external information, and I haven't been able to make sense of some stuff in Elin despite it featuring like, 4 separate help systems. Please don't use the "roguelike" label as a scapegoat to excuse disjointed, unintuitive and disorienting design. If this is the love child of dwarf fortress, kenshi and stardew valley, it sure got every single recessive gene.

(also the game tries way, way too hard for this kind of lolrandom vibe which, while it plays like an adorable time capsule of internet humor circa '05, feels forced and cringy more often than not.)

If you're thinking of playing or buying this game, by all means, please try the demo. But stick with it all the way to the end. Progress can be passed over to the full game, and to be honest, you'll probably have to restart at some point anyway so whatever. Don't be swayed by the nice graphics and the very competent presentation, because otherwise you might realize that this game is way too unpleasant to play by the time you can't refund it anymore like yours truly.

i really wanted to like this game. for the first 20 hours or so, it actually was pretty satisfying. (excuse my hour count, i played quite a bit of it while offline.) a friend recommended this one saying that it was as complex and insane as dwarf fortress. at the time, that sounded so awesome that i simply had to take him up on it.

when my review was positive, it talked about all the crazy things that had happened as i was starting out. the pet cat being an alcoholic, receiving a quest to deliver a rather valuable but extremely heavy game table which basically *forces* you to commit mail fraud, etc etc. many people have already talked about such stories. and don't get me wrong, it genuinely was funny for a while!

the problem is that dwarf fortress's insanity is baked into the game itself, whereas elin's insanity is a collection of one-off gags that eventually grow stale. "the quest asked me to deliver what?!?!" "i can, ahem, 'watch birds' with a drunken noblewoman on a street, and that's 20% as bad as just eating cat meat?" "lmao, what did you say this person's age and gender were?" but eventually you stop paying attention to the 20-ish lines of dialog or whatnot from the random civilians, and the quests become the same old thing repeatedly. and all that's left is the gameplay.

it's a total grindfest, basically. i once said that "it's OSRS if it was honest about being a nightmarish capitalist hellscape," which is unfortunately more true of the core mechanics than of the game's setting. some people vibe with that, but there are better uses of my time... after the honeymoon period of setting everything up and growing out of weakling status, it devolves into visiting the same presets of dungeons over and over, travelling between a few towns and handling their quests over and over, praying that you can find something to make your plots of land ever slightly more useful. base building in particular takes a LOT of time, with a number of essential recipes locked behind randomization. beyond a certain point, your rate of income becomes basically linear (or at least, pretty hard to expand into a respectable amount). this becomes a problem when important items are worth hundreds of thousands, while you are making just thousands at a time and it is competing with the steadily-growing taxes.

the aforementioned "dwarf fortress levels of insanity" are really just the limited number of tricks you can use to counteract this tedium, taking advantage of completely randomized object composition (beach ball made of dark matter as a quest reward...) and the fact that almost all creatures in the game behave similarly. humans can have eggs, and you can have conversations with livestock. 

but, again, there's only so much you can do. the combat system is click, click, take advantage of ranged weaponry, pray you don't die. the enemies become beefier but your strategic options don't expand much to counteract that. in particular, the magic system was really cool with how you can collect different spells to defend yourself or teleport out of harm's way. until 30 or so hours in, when you've collected nearly all of the spells and realized they *don't* gradually become more complex to help deal with advanced threats. also, some combat mechanics are quite annoying with few ways to defend against. you can pour water on yourself to protect against fire, or focus on finding acidproof equipment. but there is NOTHING you can do to prevent essential equipment from being shattered by frost, other than buying coldproof blankets, which aren't cheap.

one more minor thing, there's a pretty significant tonal dissonance in this game. i mean that there's a pretty jarring contrast between the supposedly serious story and the often ridiculous, sometimes questionable, backer-suggested content. i guess some people weren't content to make a mod, lol. but this isn't a huge issue. in fact, the insanity would be welcome if that was properly, continuously reflected in the game itself.

overall, it's decent but not mindblowing. i wouldn't bother if it's not on sale. fun for a while, but you might be making a heck of an effort to see the late-game content.
